captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: Welcome to my home
movie of the new McLaren
12C Spider.

It costs 195,500 pounds, which
is 19 and 1/2 thousand more
than the coupe.

It uses a folding hard top that
folds in just 17 seconds.

That's right, you clever people,
the opening shot was
actually speeded up.

The rear screen is electric, and
you can lower it with the

roof up to allow some more
V8 noise into the cabin.

Apart from a new, smaller
bonnet badge, the 12C is

pretty much as before, and
that's to say far more

interesting up close
than in pictures.

There are some great shapes
and scoops on this car and

some lovely sculpted details,
especially around the rear
tail pipes.

But just like the 458 Spider,
which is a very similar roof

arrangement, those buttresses
do look a bit odd from the
front three quarter view.

Allowing natural light into the
cabin makes it look even
better than before.

If the exterior styling is a
bit easy [INAUDIBLE], the

cabin is just what you'd expect
from McLaren, simple,

clever, and with some
of the coolest clock
faces on any new car.

And just to remind those of you
who have forgotten, the

12C has a chassis unlike
any other motor car.

The dampers are all
hydraulically connected, which

allows support to be transferred
to each corner in
fractions of a second.

The test car was running
optional carbon ceramic disks,

the stickier, thready,
coarser tires, and
lightweight alloy wheels.

We were at Ascari race resort,
to only seem sensible to see

how much damage chopping the
roof from a 12C has actually
caused to the way it drives.

OK, children, this is the
MP4-12C Spider, or as we now

have to call it, the 12C Spider
because they're sort of
dropping the MP4 bit.

We're at Ascari circuit,
which is a mecca
for going very fast.

But there's lots of stuff to
hit, so we have to treat it
with some respect.
So what are we looking for?

Well, I'm not sure actually,
because we know that the car

is 40 kilograms heavier,
but we also know it's
got a carbon top.

So it doesn't matter that
the roof's been removed.

That in itself should mean that,
dynamically, the car is
very similar.

Tell you what it is,
fecking quick.

This has got the upgraded
motor in it, 625 PS.
Fuck me, it's proper fast.

I mean, convertibles should
not be this much fun.

Convertibles, right, are for
sissies, but this is a bloody
animal, this thing.

The performance is
just barking.

You can hear the traction
going [INAUDIBLE].

I have to say, in super stiff
mode, there is something a

little bit artificial about the
way the chassis feels, but

do you know what, it's
not like any other
car you get to drive.

That's what I find so
interesting about it.
Oop, got that all wrong.

This is unlike any other
car out there.
It's just so flipping capable.

Definitely feels quicker than
the last one I drove.
It's just so clever.

I don't know whether to
respect it for doing

everything for me,
or to resent it.
It's difficult to decide.
What it is is very good.

As the tires are getting hotter,
I'm getting a little
bit of understeer.
I'll give you that.
I love that, ba-ba-ba.

The direction changes on the
car are remarkable, and it

just, obviously, has no flex
at all, absolutely no flex.

If there is a difference between
Spider and Coupe, I
couldn't pick it on the track.

And once we've done the sensible
fast stuff, it only

seemed right to prove that the
Spider somehow skids like it

has an LSD when it doesn't
have an LSD.

But perhaps the biggest surprise
is on the road, where

the latest gearbox and engine
calibration makes the car
smoother and faster.

In fact, it is just
crazy fast.
Is it a good convertible?

Well, the hood mechanism is
excellent, but I thought the

cabin was quite windy
at 85 miles an hour.

McLaren reckons 80% of 12Cs sold
will now be Spiders, and
I can see why.

Me, I always prefer a
roof over my head,
so I'd take a Coupe.

Either way, you get an
outstanding machine.

title: McLaren MP4-12C Spider First Drive - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
I think this is a case where I'd take the Spyder, and I'm pretty 
purist...if you're not giving up chassis rigidity and the car is not going 
to be driven in inclement weather, the option to put the roof down makes 
the car fun at normal traffic speeds on a nice day as well. 40kg would be a 
deal breaker for me for most cars, but at this level of power, I think it 
would be an acceptable tradeoff for the convertible roof.

driven by a roaring V8?

comments.text:
These just arrived in California. Expensive, and a bit too plastic compared 
to the Italia, which is just as much plastic, but somehow better in the 
finished product. A bit too bland as well, in an odd sort of way. I wonder 
if that smoke out the rear of the car was the tires or the rear brakes 
"faking" the LSD? I was thinking the coupe of the 12C was going to limit 
Porsche in the price range, but now, I'm not so sure. Hopefully the rumored 
"track" version of the 12C will be much improved.
comments.author: adamgreen222

comments.text:
A wonderful physics lesson and a indisputably properly fast car but Chris 
didnt smile once the whole time. And it only got one *hoo-hoo*. If it 
doesnt make chris smile, i lose interest, watch the huayra review, or the 
C63 on 155's. Now those are cars i want to drive!
